content: The American Legion 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act is a legislation that recognizes the founding of The American Legion in 1919. The Act highlights the growth of The American Legion as the largest veterans service organization in the United States and its role in establishing the first United States Flag Code. The American Legion played a crucial role in advocating for the G.I. Bill of Rights during World War II, leading to significant societal changes in the United States such as democratizing higher education, promoting home ownership, improving VA hospitals, and providing business and farm loans for veterans. The American Legion's advocacy for the G.I. Bill led to significant societal changes in the US, including democratizing higher education and promoting home ownership. The G.I. Bill provided a high return on investment for the economy, and the Legion established the National Emergency Fund to aid veterans after natural disasters. They also pushed for the elevation of the Veterans Administration to Cabinet-level status. The American Legion's advocacy efforts led to the creation of the United States Court of Veterans Appeals in 1988 and the American Legacy Scholarship Fund for children of military members killed on active duty. In 2016, the scholarship criteria was expanded to include children of veterans with 50 percent or greater VA disability ratings. Bush signed the Post-9/11 Veterans Educational Assistance Act in 2008, a comprehensive educational benefits package. The American Legion will celebrate its centennial in August 2018 at the National Convention in Minneapolis and in March 2019 in Paris, France. The organization's Federal charter will mark its 100th anniversary on September 16, 2019. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins in recognition of The American Legion's 100th anniversary. The coins will have specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions as outlined in the Act. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins will be emblematic of The American Legion, with inscriptions including the denomination, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items, with designs emblematic of The American Legion. The Secretary will select the design in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and The American Legion, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee will review it. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, and can only be issued during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2019. They will be sold at a price based on the face value of the coins. The Secretary will sell coins at a price based on face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges for coins minted under this Act will be included in sales. The Secretary will include surcharges for coins minted under this Act, with specific amounts for different denominations. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to The American Legion for promoting veteran care, supporting active-duty military, and upholding patriotic values. The Act includes promoting American values, strong families, and assistance for at-risk children. No surcharge can be added if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program limit. Recipients are subject to audit requirements. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES: The Secretary must ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the US Government, and no funds are disbursed until all costs are recovered.
